The brown bear is [[extinct]] in: [[Algeria]], [[Belgium]], [[Denmark]], [[Egypt]], [[Germany]], [[Hungary]], [[Republic of Ireland|Ireland]], [[Israel]], [[Jordan]], [[Lebanon]], [[Liechtenstein]], [[Lithuania]], [[Luxembourg]], [[Mexico]], [[Moldova]], [[Monaco]], [[Morocco]], [[Netherlands]], [[Portugal]], [[San Marino]], [[Switzerland]], [[Syria]], [[Tunisia]], [[United Kingdom]]. It is possibly extinct in [[Bhutan]].<ref name=IUCN/>

==Behavior and life history==
[[File:Ursus arctos - Norway.jpg|thumb|upright|Like all bears, brown bears can stand on their hindlegs and walk for a few steps in this position, usually motivated to do so by curiosity, hunger or alarm.]]
The brown bear is often described as [[nocturnal]]. However, it frequently seems to peak in activity in the morning and early evening hours.<ref name="Brown / Grizzly Bear Facts">{{cite web|title=Brown / Grizzly Bear Facts|url=http://www.bear.org/website/bear-pages/brown-or-grizzly-bear/68-brown-grizzly-bear-facts.html|publisher=North American Bear Center}}</ref> Studies have shown that activity throughout the range can occur at nearly any time of night or day, with bears who dwell in areas with more extensive human contact being more likely to be fully nocturnal. Furthermore, yearling and newly independent bears are more likely to be active diurnally and many adult bears in low-disturbance areas are largely [[crepuscular]].<ref>{{cite journal|author=Klinka, D. R., and Reimchen, T. E. |title=Nocturnal and diurnal foraging behaviour of brown bears (''Ursus arctos'') on a salmon stream in coastal British Columbia|journal=Canadian Journal of Zoology|volume=80|issue=8|page=1317−1322 |doi=10.1139/z02-123|url=http://web.uvic.ca/~reimlab/noctdibrbear.pdf|year=2002}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author=Moe, T. F., Kindberg, J., Jansson, I., & Swenson, J. E. |title=Importance of diel behaviour when studying habitat selection: examples from female Scandinavian brown bears (''Ursus arctos'')|journal=Canadian Journal of Zoology |volume=85 |issue=4 |page=518−525 |doi=10.1139/Z07-034|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/237154208|year=2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author=Kaczensky, P., Huber, D., Knauer, F., Roth, H., Wagner, A., & Kusak, J. |title=Activity patterns of brown bears (''Ursus arctos'') in Slovenia and Croatia|journal=Journal of Zoology |volume=269|issue=4|page=474−485 |doi=10.1111/j.1469-7998.2006.00114.x|year=2006}}</ref> In summer through autumn, a brown bear can double its weight from the spring, gaining up to {{Convert|180|kg|lb|abbr=on}} of [[fat]], on which it relies to make it through winter, when it becomes very lethargic.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Kingsley, M. C. S., Nagy, J. A., & Russell, R. H. |title=Patterns of weight gain and loss for grizzly bears in northern Canada|journal=Bears: Their Biology and Management |volume=5 |pages=174–178|jstor=3872535|doi=10.2307/3872535|year=1983}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author=Hissa, R., Hohtola, E., Tuomala-Saramäki, T., Laine, T., & Kallio, H. |title=Seasonal changes in fatty acids and leptin contents in the plasma of the European brown bear (''Ursus arctos arctos'')|journal= Annales Zoologici Fennici |pages=215–224|jstor=23735612|volume=35|issue=4|year=1998}}</ref> Although they are not full [[hibernation|hibernators]] and can be woken easily, both sexes like to [[maternity den|den]] in a protected spot during the winter months. Hibernation dens may consist of any spot that provides cover from the elements and that can accommodate their bodies, such as a [[cave]], crevice, cavernous tree roots, or hollow logs.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Farley, S. D., & Robbins, C. T. |title=Lactation, hibernation, and mass dynamics of American black bears and grizzly bears|journal=Canadian Journal of Zoology |volume=73 |issue=12|page=2216−2222 |doi=10.1139/z95-262|year=1995}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author=Evans, A. L., Sahlén, V., Støen, O. G., Fahlman, Å., Brunberg, S., Madslien, K., Forbert, O., Swenson, J.E. & Arnemo, J. M. |title=Capture, anesthesia, and disturbance of free-ranging brown bears (''Ursus arctos'') during hibernation|journal=PLoS ONE |volume=7 |issue=7 |pages=e40520 |doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0040520 |pmid=22815757 |pmc=3398017|year=2012|bibcode=2012PLoSO...740520E}}</ref>

Brown bears have one of the largest brains of any extant carnivoran relative to their body size and have been shown to engage in tool-use (e.g. using a barnacle-covered rock to scratch its neck), which requires advanced cognitive abilities.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Deecke, V. B. |title=Tool-use in the brown bear (''Ursus arctos'')|journal=Animal Cognition|volume=15|issue=4|pages=725–730|pmid=22367156|year=2012|doi=10.1007/s10071-012-0475-0}}</ref> This species is mostly solitary, although bears may gather in large numbers at major food sources (e.g., [[moth]] colonies, open garbage dumps or rivers holding spawning [[salmon]]) and form social hierarchies based on age and size.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Egbert | first1 = Allan L. | last2 = Stokes | first2 = Allen W. | year = 1974 | title = The social behaviour of brown bears on an Alaskan salmon stream | url =http://www.bearbiology.com/fileadmin/tpl/Downloads/URSUS/Vol_3/Egbert_Stokes_Egbert_Vol_3.pdf | format=PDF | journal = International Conference Bear Res. And Manage | volume = 3 | pages = 41–56 | jstor=3872753 | last3 = Egbert | first3 = A. L. | doi=10.2307/3872753}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=Sandell, M. |year=1989|chapter=The mating tactics and spacing patterns of solitary carnivores|title=Carnivore behavior, ecology, and evolution |pages= 164–182|publisher= Springer |isbn=978-1-4613-0855-3|doi=10.1007/978-1-4613-0855-3_7}}</ref> Adult male bears are particularly aggressive and are avoided by adolescent and subadult males both at concentrated feeding opportunities and chance encounters. Female bears with cubs rival adult males in aggression, and are much more intolerant of other bears than single females. Young adolescent males tend to be least aggressive, and have been observed in nonantagonistic interactions with each other.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Gau, R. J., McLoughlin, P. D., Case, R., Cluff, H. D., Mulders, R., & Messier, F. |year=2004|title=Movements of subadult male grizzly bears, ''Ursus arctos'', in the central Canadian arctic|journal= The Canadian Field-Naturalist|volume= 118|issue=2|pages= 239–242|url=http://journals.sfu.ca/cfn/index.php/cfn/article/view/920|doi=10.22621/cfn.v118i2.920}}</ref><ref name= Dahle>{{cite journal|author=Dahle, B., & Swenson, J. E. |title=Seasonal range size in relation to reproductive strategies in brown bears ''Ursus arctos''|journal=Journal of Animal Ecology|volume=72|issue=4|pages=660–667|doi=10.1046/j.1365-2656.2003.00737.x|jstor=3505643|year=2003}}</ref> [[Dominance (ethology)|Dominance]] between bears is asserted by making a frontal orientation, showing off canines, muzzle twisting and neck stretching to which a subordinate will respond with a lateral orientation, by turning away and dropping the head and by sitting or lying down.<ref>Stonorov, Derek and Stokes, Allen W. (1972) [http://www.bearbiology.com/fileadmin/tpl/Downloads/URSUS/Vol_2/Stonorov_Stokes.pdf "Social Behavior of the Alaska Brown Bear"] ''Panel 4: Bear Behaviour''</ref> During combat, bears use their paws to strike their opponents in the chest or shoulders and bite the head or neck. In his ''Great Bear Almanac'', Gary Brown lists 11 different sounds bears produce in 9 different contexts. Sounds expressing anger or aggravation include growls, roars, woofs, champs and smacks, while sounds expressing nervousness or pain include woofs, grunts, and bawls. Sows will bleat or hum when communicating with their cubs.<ref name="brown"/>

===Home ranges===
Brown bears usually occur over vast home ranges, however they are not highly territorial. Several adult bears often roam freely over the same vicinity without issue unless rights to a fertile female or food sources are being contested.<ref name= Smith/><ref name= Dahle/> Males always cover more area than females each year. Despite their lack of traditional territorial behavior, adult males can seem to have a "personal zone" in which other bears are not tolerated if they are seen.<ref name= Pearson>Pearson, A. M. (1975). ''The northern interior grizzly bear Ursus arctos L. '' Information Canada.</ref> Males always wander further than females due to both increasing access to females and food sources while females are advantaged by smaller territories in part since it decreases the likelihood of encounters with male bears who may endanger their cubs.<ref name= Smith/><ref name= Novak/><ref name= Feldhamer/><ref name= Bellemain>{{cite journal|doi=10.1111/j.1439-0310.2006.01152.x|title=Mating Strategies in Relation to Sexually Selected Infanticide in a Non-Social Carnivore: The Brown Bear|url=http://bearproject.info/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/2006-A060-Bellemain-Mating-Strategies-in-relation-to-SSI.pdf|journal=Ethology|volume=112|issue=3|pages=238–246|year=2006|last1=Bellemain|first1=Eva|last2=Swenson|first2=Jon E.|last3=Taberlet|first3=Pierre}}</ref> In areas where food is abundant and concentrated, such as coastal Alaska, home ranges for females are up to {{convert|24|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}} and for males are up to {{convert|89|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}}. Similarly, in [[British Columbia]], bears of the two sexes travel relatively compact home ranges of {{convert|115|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}} and {{convert|318|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}}. In [[Yellowstone National Park]], home ranges for females are up to {{convert|281|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}} and up to {{convert|874|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}} for males. In [[Romania]], the largest home range was recorded for adult males (3,143 km<sup>2</sup>, 1214 sq mi).<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Pop|first=Ioan Mihai|last2=Bereczky|first2=Leonardo|last3=Chiriac|first3=Silviu|last4=Iosif|first4=Ruben|last5=Nita|first5=Andreea|last6=Popescu|first6=Viorel Dan|last7=Rozylowicz|first7=Laurențiu|title=Movement ecology of brown bears (Ursus arctos) in the Romanian Eastern Carpathians|url=https://natureconservation.pensoft.net/articles.php?id=22955|journal=Nature Conservation|language=en|volume=26|pages=15–31|doi=10.3897/natureconservation.26.22955|issn=1314-3301|via=|year=2018}}</ref>  In the central Arctic of Canada, where food sources are quite sparse, home ranges range up to {{convert|2434|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}} in females and {{convert|8171|km2|sqmi|abbr=on}} in males.<ref name= Smith/><ref name="Hunter"/><ref name= Novak/><ref name= Dahle/>

A study of male-inherited [[Y chromosome]] [[DNA]] sequence found that brown bears, over the past few 10,000 years, have shown strong [[Inbreeding avoidance|male-biased dispersal]].<ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1093/molbev/msu109| pmid = 24667925| title = Brown and Polar Bear Y Chromosomes Reveal Extensive Male-Biased Gene Flow within Brother Lineages| journal = Molecular Biology and Evolution| volume = 31| issue = 6| pages = 1353–1363| year = 2014| last1 = Bidon | first1 = T.| last2 = Janke | first2 = A.| last3 = Fain | first3 = S. R.| last4 = Eiken | first4 = H. G.| last5 = Hagen | first5 = S. B.| last6 = Saarma | first6 = U.| last7 = Hallstrom | first7 = B. M.| last8 = Lecomte | first8 = N.| last9 = Hailer | first9 = F.}}</ref> That study found surprisingly similar Y chromosomes in brown bear populations as far apart as Norway and coastal Alaska, indicating extensive [[gene flow]] across [[Eurasia]] and [[North America]]. Notably, this contrasts with genetic signals from female-inherited [[mitochondrial DNA]] (mtDNA), where brown bears of different geographic regions typically show strong differences in their mtDNA, a result of female [[philopatry]].

===Reproduction===
[[File:Ähtärin karhut 24.jpg|thumb|Pair of mating brown bears at the [[Ähtäri Zoo]] in [[Ähtäri|Ähtäri, Finland]]]]
The [[mating season]] is from mid-May to early July, shifting later the further north the bears are found.<ref name="Hunter"/><ref name= Feldhamer/><ref>{{cite journal|author=Herrero, S., & Hamer, D. |year=1977|title=Courtship and copulation of a pair of grizzly bears, with comments on reproductive plasticity and strategy|jstor=1379352|doi=10.2307/1379352|journal=Journal of Mammalogy|volume= 58|issue=3|pages=441–444}}</ref> Being [[serially monogamous]], brown bears remain with the same mate from a couple of days to a couple of weeks.<ref name= Smith/><ref>[http://www.bear-hunting.org/types-of-bears/ Types of Bears] – Information on Specific Bear Species (2009)</ref> Outside of this narrow time frame, adult male and female brown bears show no sexual interest in each other.<ref name= Smith/> Females mature sexually between the age of 4 and 8 years of age, with an average age at sexual maturity of 5.2–5.5 years old, while males first mate about a year later on average, when they are large and strong enough to successfully compete with other males for mating rights.<ref name= Craighead/><ref name= Pearson/><ref name= White>{{cite journal|author=White, D.J., Berardinelli, J.G. & Aune, K.E. |year=1998|title=Reproductive characteristics of the male grizzly bear in the continental United States|jstor=3873161|journal=Ursus |volume=10|pages=497–501}}</ref> Males will try to mate with as many females as they can, usually a successful one mates with two females in a span of one to three weeks.<ref name= Walker/><ref name= White/> The adult female brown bear is similarly promiscuous, mating with up to four, rarely even eight, males while in heat and potentially breeding with two males in a single day. Females come into oestrus on average every three to four years, with a full range of 2.4 to 5.7 years. The urine markings of a female in oestrus can attract several males via scent.<ref name= Novak/><ref name= Feldhamer/><ref name= Nawaz/><ref name= Bellemain/><ref>{{cite journal|author=Halloran, D. W., & Pearson, A. M. |year=1972|title=Blood chemistry of the brown bear (''Ursus arctos'') from southwestern Yukon Territory, Canada|doi=10.1139/z72-112|journal=Canadian Journal of Zoology|volume= 50|issue=6|pages=827–833}}</ref> Paternity DNA tests have shown that up to 29% of cubs in a litter will be from two to three different males.<ref name= Bellemain/> Dominant males may try to sequester a female for her entire oestrus period of approximately two weeks but usually are unable to retain her for the entire time.<ref name= Feldhamer/><ref name= Bellemain/> Copulation is vigorous and prolonged and can last up to an hour, although the mean time is about 23–24 minutes.<ref name= Feldhamer/><ref>{{cite journal|author=Craighead, J. J., Hornocker, M. G., & Craighead Jr, F. C. |year=1969|title=Reproductive biology of young female grizzly bears|journal= J. Reprod. Fert. |volume=Suppl 6|pages= 447–475}}</ref>

[[File:Grizzly Bear- Sow and cubs (5728173840).jpg|thumb|left|Grizzly bear cubs often imitate their mothers closely.]]
Males take no part in raising their cubs – parenting is left entirely to the females.<ref name= Dahle/><ref name= Corbet>Corbet, G. B. (1966). ''Terrestrial mammals of Western Europe''. G.T. Foulic & Co. Ltd., London, UK.</ref> Through the process of [[delayed implantation]], a female's fertilized egg divides and floats freely in the uterus for six months. During winter dormancy, the fetus attaches to the [[uterus|uterine]] wall. The cubs are born eight weeks later, while the mother sleeps. If the mother does not gain enough weight to survive through the winter, the embryo does not implant and is reabsorbed into the body.<ref name= Craighead/><ref>{{cite journal |last-author-amp=yes |author1=Tsubota, T. |author2=Kanagawa, H. |year=1993|title=Morphological Characteristics of the Ovary, Uterus and Embryo during the Delayed Implantation Period in the Hokkaido Brown Bear (''Ursus arctos yesoensis'')|url=https://www.jstage.jst.go.jp/article/jrd1992/39/4/39_4_325/_article|journal=Journal of Reproduction and Development|volume= 39|issue=4|pages=325–331|doi=10.1262/jrd.39.325}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last-author-amp=yes |author1=Hensel, R. J. |author2=Troyer, W. A. |author3=Erickson, A. W. |year=1969|title=Reproduction in the female brown bear|jstor=3799836|journal=The Journal of Wildlife Management|pages= 357–365|volume=33|issue=2 |doi=10.2307/3799836}}</ref> There have been cases of bears with as many as six cubs, although the average litter size is 1-3, with more than four being considered uncommon.<ref name= Craighead/><ref>{{cite journal |last-author-amp=yes |author1=Frković, A. |author2=Huber, D. |author3=Kusak, J. |year=2001|title=Brown bear litter sizes in Croatia|jstor=3873235|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/247768086|journal=Ursus|volume=12 |pages=103–105}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.bearbiology.com/fileadmin/tpl/Downloads/IBN_Newsletters/IBN_May_2005.pdf |author1=Pazetnov, V.A. |author2=Pazetnov, S.V. |last-author-amp=yes |year=2005|title=Female brown bear with six cubs|journal= International Bear News |volume=14|issue=2|page=17}}</ref> There are records of females sometimes adopting stray cubs or even trading or kidnapping cubs when they emerge from hibernation (a larger female may claim cubs away from a smaller one).<ref name="Hunter"/><ref>{{cite journal|author=Erickson, A. W., & Miller, L. H. |year=1963|title=Cub adoption in the brown bear|journal=Journal of Mammalogy|volume= 44 |issue=4 |pages=584–585 |doi=10.2307/1377153 |jstor=1377153}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|url=https://pubs.er.usgs.gov/publication/1012856|author=Barnes Jr, V., & Smith, R. |year=1993|title=Cub adoption by brown bears (''Ursus arctos middendorffi'') on Kodiak Island, Alaska|journal=Canadian Field-Naturalist|volume= 107|pages= 365–367}}</ref> Older and larger females within a population tend to give birth to larger litters<ref>{{cite journal|author=Stringham, S. F. |year=1990|title=Grizzly bear reproductive rate relative to body size|journal=Bears: Their Biology and Management|volume=8|pages= 433–443|doi=10.2307/3872948|url=https://www.bearbiology.com/fileadmin/tpl/Downloads/URSUS/Vol_8/Stringham_Grizzly_8.pdf|jstor=3872948}}</ref> The size of a litter also depends on factors such as geographic location and food supply.<ref name= Steyaert>{{cite journal|author=Steyaert, S. M., Endrestol, A., Hacklaender, K., Swenson, J. E., & Zedrosser, A. |year=2012|title=The mating system of the brown bear ''Ursus arctos''|doi=10.1111/j.1365-2907.2011.00184.x|journal= Mammal Review|volume= 42|issue=1|pages=12–34}}</ref> At birth, the cubs are blind, toothless, hairless, and may weigh from {{Convert|350|to|510|g|lb|abbr=on}}, again reportedly based on the age and condition of the mother.<ref>Couturier MA (1954). ''L’ours Brun, Ursus arctos. L.'' Couturier, Grenoble, France.</ref> They feed on their mother's milk until spring or even early summer, depending on climate conditions. At this time, the cubs weigh {{Convert|7|to|9|kg|lb|abbr=on}} and have developed enough to follow her over long distances and begin to forage for solid food.<ref name= Mallinson/><ref>{{cite journal|author=Dahle, B., Zedrosser, A., & Swenson, J. E. |year=2006|title=Correlates with body size and mass in yearling brown bears (''Ursus arctos'')|doi=10.1111/j.1469-7998.2006.00127.x|journal=Journal of Zoology|volume= 269|issue=3|pages=273–283}}</ref>

[[File:Kodiak brown bears FWS 18385.jpg|thumb|Kodiak bear cubs play fighting]]
The cubs are fully dependent on the mother and a close bond is formed. During the dependency stage, the cubs learn (rather than inherit as instincts from birth) survival techniques, such as which foods have the highest nutritional value and where to obtain them; how to hunt, fish, and defend themselves; and where to den.<ref name= Novak/> Increased brain size in large carnivores has been positively linked to whether a given species is solitary, as is the brown bear, or raises their offspring communally, thus female brown bears have relatively large, well-developed brains presumably key in teaching behavior.<ref>{{cite journal|pmid=8202515|pmc=44022 |author=Gittleman, J. L. |year=1994|title=Female brain size and parental care in carnivores|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences|volume=91|issue=12|pages=5495–5497|bibcode=1994PNAS...91.5495G|doi=10.1073/pnas.91.12.5495}}</ref> The cubs learn by following and imitating their mother's actions during the period they are with her.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.shadowofthebear.com/reproduction.html |title=Brown Bear Reproduction |publisher=Shadowofthebear.com |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080501092730/http://www.shadowofthebear.com/reproduction.html |archivedate = 1 May 2008}}</ref> Cubs remain with their mother for an average of 2.5 years in [[North America]], uncommonly being independent as early as 1.5 years of age or as late as 4.5 years of age.<ref name= Feldhamer/> The stage at which independence is attained may generally be earlier in some parts of [[Eurasia]], as the latest date which mother cubs were together was 2.3 years and most families separated in under two years in a study from [[Hokkaido]] and in [[Sweden]] most cubs on their own were still yearlings.<ref name=mano>{{cite journal|author1=Mano, T. |author2=Tsubota, T. |year=2002|title=Reproductive characteristics of brown bears on the Oshima peninsula, Hokkaido, Japan|jstor=1383508|doi=10.1644/1545-1542(2002)083<1026:RCOBBO>2.0.CO;2|journal=Journal of Mammalogy|volume= 83|issue=4|pages=1026–1034}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author=Dahle, B., & Swenson, J. E. |year=2003|title=Family breakup in brown bears: are young forced to leave?|doi=10.1644/1545-1542(2003)084<0536:FBIBBA>2.0.CO;2|journal= Journal of Mammalogy|volume= 84|issue=2|pages=536–540}}</ref> Brown bears practice [[infanticide (zoology)|infanticide]], as an adult male bear may kill the cubs of another bear.<ref name= Bellemain/> When adult male brown bears kill a cub it is usually because he is bringing the female into oestrus, as she will enter that state within 2–4 days after the death of her cubs.<ref name= Bellemain/> Cubs flee up a tree, if available, when they see a strange male bear, and the mother often successfully defends them, even though the male may be twice as heavy as she, although females have been known to lose their lives in these confrontations.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Bellemain, E., Zedrosser, A., Manel, S., Waits, L. P., Taberlet, P., & Swenson, J. E. |year=2006|pmid=16543170|pmc=1560043|title=The dilemma of female mate selection in the brown bear, a species with sexually selected infanticide|journal=Proceedings of the Royal Society of London B: Biological Sciences|volume= 273|issue=1584|pages=283–291|doi=10.1098/rspb.2005.3331}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author=Swenson, J. E., Dahle, B., & Sandegren, F. |year=2001|title=Intraspecific predation in Scandinavian brown bears older than cubs-of-the-year|journal=Ursus|pages= 81–91|jstor=3873233|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/237374836|volume=12}}</ref><ref name="Mörner">{{cite journal|author=Mörner, T., Eriksson, H., Bröjer, C., Nilsson, K., Uhlhorn, H., Ågren, E., af Segerstad, C.H., Jansson, D.S. & Gavier-Widén, D. |year=2005|title=Diseases and mortality in free-ranging brown bear (''Ursus arctos''), gray wolf (''Canis lupus''), and wolverine (''Gulo gulo'') in Sweden|journal=Journal of Wildlife Diseases|volume= 41|issue=2|pages=298–303|pmid=16107663|doi=10.7589/0090-3558-41.2.298}}</ref>

===Longevity and mortality===
[[File:Bear hunting Kodiak FWS.jpg|thumb|left|upright|A hunter with the head of a [[Kodiak bear]] on his back]]
The brown bear is a naturally long-lived animal. Wild females have been observed reproducing up to 28 years of age, which is the oldest known age for reproduction of any [[bear|ursid]] in the wild. The peak reproductive age for females ranges from 4 to 20 years old.<ref name="Hunter"/><ref>{{cite journal|author=Schwartz, C. C., Keating, K. A., Reynolds III, H. V., Barnes Jr, V. G., Sellers, R. A., Swenson, J. E., Miller, S.D. McLellan, B., Keay, J., McCann, R., Gibeau, M. Wakkinen, W.F. Mace, R.D., Kasworm, W. Smith, R. & Herrero, S. |year=2003|title=Reproductive maturation and senescence in the female brown bear|journal= Ursus|pages= 109–119|jstor=3873012|volume=14|issue=2}}</ref> The lifespan of brown bears of both sexes within minimally hunted populations is estimated at an average of 25 years.<ref name= encyclopedia>McDonald, D., & Norris, S. (2001). ''The new encyclopedia of mammals''. Oxford University Press.</ref> The oldest wild brown bear on record was nearly 37 years old.<ref name= encyclopedia/> The oldest recorded female in captivity was nearly 40 years old, while males in captivity have been verified to live up to 47 years, with one captive male possibly attaining 50 years of age.<ref name= Smith/><ref name= Walker/>

While male bears potentially live longer in captivity, female grizzly bears have a greater annual survival rate than males within wild populations per a study done in the [[Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem]].<ref>{{cite journal|author=Schwartz, C. C., Haroldson, M. A., White, G. C., Harris, R. B., Cherry, S., Keating, K. A., Moody, D. & Servheen, C. |title=Temporal, Spatial, and Environmental Influences on the Demographics of Grizzly Bears in the Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem |journal=Wildlife Monographs|volume=161|pages=1−68|doi=10.2193/0084-0173(2006)161[1:TSAEIO]2.0.CO;2|year=2006}}</ref> Annual mortality for bears of any age is estimated at around 10% in most protected areas;<ref name="Hunter"/> however, the average annual mortality rate rises to an estimated 38% in hunted populations.<ref name="Hunter"/> Around 13% to 44% of cubs die within their first year even in well-protected areas.<ref name= Smith/> Mortality rates of 75–100% among the cubs of any given year are not uncommon.<ref name= compendium>Servheen, C. (1987). ''Grizzly bear compendium''. Interagency Grizzly Bear Committee.</ref> Beyond predation by large predators including [[Gray wolf|wolves]], [[Siberian tiger]]s (''Panthera tigris altaica'') and other brown bears, starvation and accidents also claim the lives of cubs. Studies have indicated that the most prevalent source of mortality for first-year cubs is malnutrition.<ref name= Smith/><ref name= Novak/><ref name="Mörner"/><ref name= Palomares>{{cite journal|author1=Palomares, F. |author2=Caro, T. M.  |author2link=Tim Caro |title=Interspecific Killing among Mammalian Carnivores |url=http://digital.csic.es/bitstream/10261/51387/1/Palomares%20&%20Caro_1999_Am%20Nat.pdf |journal=The American Naturalist|volume=153|issue=5|pages=492–508  |doi=10.1086/303189|pmid=29578790  |year=1999|hdl=10261/51387  }}</ref> By the second and third years of their lives, the annual mortality rate among cubs in the care of their mothers drops to 10-15%.<ref name= Novak/>

Even in populations living in protected areas, humans are still the leading cause of mortality for brown bears.<ref name= Servheen/><ref name= encyclopedia/><ref name="Brown Bear Hunting Alaska">{{cite web|title=Brown/Grizzly Bear Hunting in Alaska|url=http://www.adfg.alaska.gov/index.cfm?adfg=brownbearhunting.main|publisher=Alaska Department of Fish and Game}}</ref> The largest amount of legalized brown bear hunting occurs in Canada, Finland, Russia, Slovakia and Alaska.<ref name="Hunter"/> Hunting is unregulated in many areas within the range of the brown bear. Even where hunting is legally permitted most biologists feel that the numbers hunted are excessive considering the low reproduction rate and sparse distribution of the species.<ref name= Servheen/><ref name= Mallinson/><ref name= compendium/> Brown bears are also killed in collisions with automobiles, which is a significant cause of mortality in the United States and Europe.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Huber, D., Kusak, J., & Frkovic, A. |year=1998|title=Traffic kills of brown bears in Gorski kotar, Croatia|journal=Ursus|pages= 167–171|jstor=3873124|volume=10}}</ref><ref>Servheen, C., Waller, J., & Kasworm, W. (1998). ''Fragmentation effects of high-speed highways on grizzly bear populations shared between the United States and Canada''. International Conference on Wildlife Ecology and Transportation (ICOWET 1998).</ref>

==Dietary habits==
[[File:Brown Bear Feeding on Salmon.jpg|thumb|upright|Brown bear feeding on [[salmon]]]]
The brown bear is one of the most [[omnivorous]] animals in the world and has been recorded consuming the greatest variety of foods of any bear.<ref name="Hunter"/> Throughout life, this species is regularly curious about the potential of eating virtually any organism or object that they encounter. Certainly no other animal in their given ecosystems, short perhaps of other bear species and humans, can claim to feed on as broad a range of dietary opportunities. Food that is both abundant and easily obtained is preferred. Their jaw structure has evolved to fit their dietary habits. Their diet varies enormously throughout their differing areas based on opportunity.<ref name= Smith/><ref name= encyclopedia/> In spring, winter-provided carrion, grasses, shoots, sedges and forbs are the dietary mainstays for brown bears from almost every part of their distribution.<ref name="Hunter"/> Fruits, including berries, become increasingly important during summer and early autumn. Roots and bulbs become critical in autumn for some inland bear populations if fruit crops are poor.<ref name="Hunter"/> The dietary variability is illustrated in the western [[United States]], as meat made up 51% of the average year-around diet for grizzly bears from [[Yellowstone National Park]] while it made up only 11% of the year-around diet for grizzlies from [[Glacier National Park (U.S.)|Glacier National Park]] a few hundred miles to the north.<ref name=jac/>

===Plants and fungi===
Despite their reputation, most brown bears are not highly carnivorous, as they derive up to 90% of their dietary [[food energy]] from vegetable matter.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dced.state.ak.us/oed/student_info/learn/bearwatching.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090415202025/http://www.dced.state.ak.us/oed/student_info/learn/bearwatching.htm |archivedate=15 April 2009 |title=Alaska is bear territory!|work=Alaska Office of Economic Development |publisher=Dced.state.ak.us }}</ref> Brown bears often feed on a variety of plant life, including [[Berry|berries]], [[grass]]es, [[flower]]s, [[acorn]]s (''Quercus'' ssp.) and [[pine cone]]s as well as [[moss]]es and [[Fungus|fungi]] such as [[mushroom]]s.<ref name= Smith/> In total, over 200 plant species have been identified in their foods.<ref name= Rode>{{cite journal|author=Rode, K. D., Robbins, C. T., & Shipley, L. A. |title=Constraints on herbivory by grizzly bears|journal=Oecologia|volume=128|issue=1|pages=62–71|doi=10.1007/s004420100637|pmid=28547091|jstor=4222978|year=2001|bibcode=2001Oecol.128...62R}}</ref> Arguably the most herbivorous diets have come from the warmer temperate parts of [[Eurasia]] as more than 90% of the diet may be herbivorous. These include countries and regions such as [[Spain]], [[Slovakia]], most of the [[Balkans]] including [[Greece]], [[Turkey]], the [[Himalayas]], and presumably the [[Middle East]].<ref name= Rigg/><ref name= Nawaz/><ref name= Paralikidis/><ref name= Ambarl>{{cite journal|author=Ambarlı, H. |title=Litter size and basic diet of brown bears (''Ursus arctos'', Carnivora) in northeastern Turkey|journal=Mammalia|volume=80|issue=2|doi=10.1515/mammalia-2014-0111|year=2016}}</ref><ref name= Naves>{{cite journal|author=Naves, J., Fernández-Gil, A., Rodríguez, C., & Delibes, M. |title=Brown Bear Food Habits at the Border of Its Range: A Long-Term Study|journal=Journal of Mammalogy|volume=87|issue=5|page=899|doi=10.1644/05-MAMM-A-318R2.1|year=2006|hdl=10261/50290}}</ref> In many inland portions of North America, the diet of grizzly bears is between 80 and 90% plant-based but animal meat can be much more important in some areas.<ref name= Murie>Murie, A. (2012). ''The grizzlies of Mount McKinley''. University of Washington Press.</ref><ref name= McLellan2>{{cite journal|author=McLellan, B. N., & Hovey, F. W. |title=The diet of grizzly bears in the Flathead River drainage of southeastern British Columbia|journal=Canadian Journal of Zoology|volume=73|issue=4|page=704|doi=10.1139/z95-082|year=1995}}</ref><ref name= MacHutchon>{{cite journal|author=MacHutchon, A. G., & Wellwood, D. W. |year=2003|title=Grizzly bear food habits in the northern Yukon, Canada|journal= Ursus|pages=225–235|jstor=3873022|volume=14|issue=2}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author=Mace, R. D., & Jonkel, C. J. |title=Local Food Habits of the Grizzly Bear in Montana|journal=Bears: Their Biology and Management|volume=6|pages=105–110|url=http://www.bearbiology.com/fileadmin/tpl/Downloads/URSUS/Vol_6/Mace_Jonkel_Vol_6.pdf|doi=10.2307/3872813|jstor=3872813|year=1986}}</ref> It has been found that being restricted to a largely vegetarian diet puts constraints on the growth and size of bears who live off of them, largely because their digestive systems do not process plants as well as animal fats and proteins.<ref name= McLellan/><ref name= Rode/><ref>{{cite journal|author=Barboza, P. S., Farley, S. D., & Robbins, C. T. |title=Whole-body urea cycling and protein turnover during hyperphagia and dormancy in growing bears (''Ursus americanus'' and ''U. arctos'')|journal=Canadian Journal of Zoology|volume=75|issue=12|page=2129|doi=10.1139/z97-848|year=1997}}</ref>

Among all living bears, brown bears are uniquely equipped to dig for tough foods such as [[root]]s and [[shoot]]s. They use their long, strong claws to dig out earth to reach the roots and their powerful jaws to bite through them.<ref name= Smith/> For the most part, the consumed plant life in spring, predominantly [[root]]s immediately post-hibernation and [[Poaceae|grasses]] later in spring, is not highly nutritious for bears and mainly staves off hunger and starvation until more nutritious food is available. Brown bears have difficulty digesting large quantities of tough, fibrous foods.<ref name= compendium/><ref>{{cite journal|author=Bunnell, F. L., & Hamilton, T. |title=Forage digestibility and fitness in grizzly bears|journal=Bears: Their Biology and Management|volume=7|pages=187–197|doi=10.2307/3872625|url=http://www.bearbiology.com/fileadmin/tpl/Downloads/URSUS/Vol_5/Bunnell___Hamilton_Vol_5.pdf|jstor=3872625|year=1987}}</ref> [[Hedysarum]] roots are among the most commonly eaten foods from throughout the range and can become important substitutes if stable foods such as fruits become unavailable.<ref name= MacHutchon/><ref name= Hamer>{{cite journal|author=Hamer, D., & Herrero, S. |year=1987|title=Grizzly bear food and habitat in the front ranges of Banff National Park, Alberta|journal=Bears: Their Biology and Management|pages= 199–213|jstor=3872626|volume=7}}</ref> [[Corm]]s and [[bulb]]s are important when available as they are one of the greater sources of protein in plant life as are [[Mast (botany)|hard masts]] such as [[acorn]]s. Brown bears are restricted in their access to hard masts compared to black bears because of the limited climbing abilities of grown bears and therefore are confined largely to masts fallen to the ground, pirated from other creatures or within a reach of about {{convert|3|m|ftin|0|abbr=on}} that the bears can stretch to with their paws extended and standing on their hindlegs.<ref name= Seryodkin/> Hard masts can become the most important food (although consumed mainly in late summer and fall) where available in large quantities such as on [[Hokkaido]], [[Italy]] and [[Spain]].<ref name= compendium/><ref name= Aoi>{{cite journal|author=Aoi, T. |year=1985|title=Seasonal change in food habits of Ezo brown bear (''Ursus arctos yesoensis'' Lydekker) in northern Hokkaido|journal= Research Bulletins of the College Experiment Forests, Hokkaido University|volume= 42|issue=4|pages=721–732|url=http://eprints.lib.hokudai.ac.jp/dspace/handle/2115/21150?locale=en&lang=en}}</ref><ref name= Clevenger>{{cite journal|author=Clevenger, A. P., Purroy, F. J., & Pelton, M. R. |title=Food habits of brown bears (''Ursus arctos'') in the Cantabrian Mountains, Spain|journal=Journal of Mammalogy|volume=73|issue=2|pages=415–421|doi=10.2307/1382077|jstor=1382077|year=1992}}</ref><ref name="Ciucci, P. 2014">{{cite journal|author=Ciucci, P., Tosoni, E., Di Domenico, G., Quattrociocchi, F., & Boitani, L.|title=Seasonal and annual variation in the food habits of Apennine brown bears, central Italy|journal=Journal of Mammalogy|volume=95|issue=3|page=572|doi=10.1644/13-MAMM-A-218|year=2014}}</ref> One of the most important foods in the Rocky Mountain region of the United States is the [[Pinus albicaulis|whitebark pine nut]] (''Pinus albicaulis''), which is attained perhaps a majority of the time by raiding the once abundant caches of [[American red squirrel]]s (''Tamiasciurus hudsonicus'') rather than direct foraging.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Mattson, D. J., & Reinhart, D. P. |title=Excavation of Red Squirrel Middens by Grizzly Bears in the Whitebark Pine Zone|journal=The Journal of Applied Ecology|volume=34|issue=4|pages=926–940|jstor=2405283|doi=10.2307/2405283|year=1997}}</ref> The decline of whitebark pine nut due to the inadvertent introduction by man of the invasive, virulent fungi ''[[Cronartium ribicola]]'' has in turn required grizzlies to seek alternative food sources, many of which are carnivorous.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Mattson, D. J., Blanchard, B. M., & Knight, R. R. |title=Yellowstone Grizzly Bear Mortality, Human Habituation, and Whitebark Pine Seed Crops|journal=The Journal of Wildlife Management|volume=56|issue=3|pages=432–442|jstor=3808855|doi=10.2307/3808855|year=1992}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author=Arno, S. F. |year=1986|title=Technical Commentary: Whitebark Pine Cone Crops--A Diminishing Source of Wildlife Food?|journal= Western Journal of Applied Forestry|volume=1|issue=3|pages=92–94}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author=Keane, R. E., & Arno, S. F. |year=1993|title=Rapid decline of whitebark pine in western Montana: evidence from 20-year remeasurements|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/233582408|journal=Western Journal of Applied Forestry|volume= 8|issue=2|pages= 44–47}}</ref> In a Greek food study, soft mast were found to outrank hard masts as a food source, with about a quarter of the year-around diet consisting of the [[legume]] ''[[Medicago]]''.<ref name= Paralikidis>{{cite journal|author=Paralikidis, N. P., Papageorgiou, N. K., Kontsiotis, V. J., & Tsiompanoudis, A. C.|title=The dietary habits of the brown bear (''Ursus arctos'') in western Greece|journal=Mammalian Biology – Zeitschrift für Säugetierkunde|volume=75|page=29|doi=10.1016/j.mambio.2009.03.010|year=2010}}</ref>

[[File:Grizzly Bears in Blueberries (6187113330).jpg|thumb|left|A grizzly bear sow and her two cubs foraging in a field for wild berries]]
[[Fruit]]s and berries are indispensable for brown bears in most areas as a high-energy food stuff for bears which is necessary to survive the hibernation cycle. The variety of fruits consumed is high, with most of the well-known, wild fruiting plants in temperate North America and Eurasia attracting brown bears in late summer and fall.<ref name= compendium/><ref name= Ewer>Ewer, R. F. (1973). ''The carnivores''. Cornell University Press.</ref> Among the most prominent fruits found in their foods from through the range include many ''[[Prunus]]'' species including [[prune]]s and [[Prunus avium|cherries]], [[crowberry|crowberries]] (''Empetrum nigrum''), [[pear]]s (''Pyrus'' ssp.), [[Malus|crabapple]]s (''Malus'' ssp.), [[Rubus fruticosus|bramble]]s (''Rubus fruticosus''), [[Rubus idaeus|raspberries]] (''Rubus idaeus''), [[Bearberry|bearberries]] (''Arctostaphylos'' ssp.) (reportedly named for bears' fondness for them), [[Blueberry|blueberries]] (''Vaccinium'' ssp.), [[Vaccinium vitis-idaea|lingonberries]] (''Vaccinium vitis-idaea'') and [[Vaccinium parvifolium|huckleberries]] (''Vaccinium parvifolium'').<ref name= Paralikidis/><ref name= Murie/><ref name= McLellan2/><ref name="Hamer"/><ref name="Frąckowiak">{{cite journal|author=Frąckowiak, W., & Gula, R. |year=1992|title=The autumn and spring diet of brown bear ''Ursus arctos'' in the Bieszczady Mountains of Poland|url=http://rcin.org.pl/Content/11807/BI002_26812_Cz-40-2_Acta-T37-nr31-339-344_o.pdf|journal= Acta Theriologica|volume= 37|issue=4|pages=339–344|doi=10.4098/at.arch.92-34}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author=Cicnjak, L., Huber, D., Roth, H. U., Ruff, R. L., & Vinovrski, Z. |year=1987|title=Food habits of brown bears in Plitvice lakes national park, Yugoslavia|journal=Bears: Their Biology and Management|pages= 221–226|jstor=3872628|volume=7}}</ref> Fruit appears to become more secondary in the diet in areas where hard masts and animal protein are abundant in late summer and fall, as these more protein-rich foods appear to be more nutritious for bears than carbohydrate-rich fruits are, despite their fondness for fruit.<ref name= McLellan/><ref name= Naves/><ref>{{cite journal|author=Ohdachi, S., & Aoi, T. |year=1987|title=Food habits of brown bears in Hokkaido, Japan|journal=Bears: Their Biology and Management|volume=7|pages= 215–220|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/49466404|doi=10.2307/3872627|jstor=3872627|hdl=2115/44508}}
</ref> Even where fruit are commonly eaten, other foods must be eaten to meet nutritional requirements. It is estimated that a small female brown bear may need to eat nearly 30,000 berries each day in late summer/fall in order to subsist on a purely fruit-based diet.<ref name= McLellan/><ref>{{cite journal|author=Rode, K. D., & Robbins, C. T.|title=Why bears consume mixed diets during fruit abundance|journal=Canadian Journal of Zoology|volume=78|issue=9|page=1640|doi=10.1139/z00-082|year=2000}}</ref>

===Invertebrates===
Brown bears will also commonly consume animal matter, which in summer and autumn may regularly be in the form of [[insect]]s, [[larvae]] and [[Larva|grubs]], including [[beehive]]s. Most insects eaten are of the highly social variety found in colonial nests, which provide a likely greater quantity of food, although they will also tear apart rotten logs on the forest floor, turn over rocks or simply dig in soft earth in attempts to consume individual invertebrates such as [[Hemiptera|bugs]], [[beetle]]s and [[earthworm]]s.<ref name= Whitaker/><ref name= Prater/><ref>{{cite journal|author=Mattson, D. J., French, M. G., & French, S. P. |jstor=3873192|title=Consumption of Earthworms by Yellowstone Grizzly Bears|journal=Ursus|volume=13 |year=2002|pages=105–110 }}</ref> [[Honey bee]]s and [[wasp]]s are important supplemental foods in Eurasia from the furthest west of their range, in [[Spain]], to the furthest east, in [[Hokkaido]].<ref name= Naves/><ref name= Aoi/> Bears in [[Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem|Yellowstone]] and [[Montana]] eat an enormous number of [[moth]]s during the summer, sometimes consuming as many as 40,000 [[Army cutworm|army cutworm moths]] (''Euxoa auxiliaris'') in a single day, and may derive up to half of their annual food energy from these insects.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.yellowstonepark.com/MoreToKnow/ShowNewsDetails.aspx?newsid=163 |title=Yellowstone Grizzly Bears Eat 40,000 Moths a Day In August |publisher=Yellowstonepark.com |date=21 June 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100715011549/http://www.yellowstonepark.com/moretoknow/shownewsdetails.aspx?newsid=163 |archivedate=15 July 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author=Mattson, D. J., Gillin, C. M., Benson, S. A., & Knight, R. R. |title=Bear feeding activity at alpine insect aggregation sites in the Yellowstone ecosystem|journal=Canadian Journal of Zoology|volume=69|issue=9|page=2430|doi=10.1139/z91-341|year=1991}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author=White, Jr, D., Kendall, K. C., & Picton, H. D. |title=Grizzly bear feeding activity at alpine army cutworm moth aggregation sites in northwest Montana|journal=Canadian Journal of Zoology|volume=76|issue=2|page=221|doi=10.1139/z97-185|year=1998}}</ref> In [[Europe]], a variety of species of ants have been found to factor heavily into the diet in some areas such as [[Scandinavia]] and [[eastern Europe]]. In [[Slovenia]], for example, up to 25% of the dry mass consumed by bears was ants.<ref name= Swenson3>{{cite journal|author=Swenson, J. E., Jansson, A., Riig, R., & Sandegren, F.|title=Bears and ants: Myrmecophagy by brown bears in central Scandinavia|journal=Canadian Journal of Zoology|volume=77|issue=4|page=551|doi=10.1139/z99-004|year=1999}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author=Große, C., Kaczensky, P., & Knauer, F. |title=Ants: A food source sought by Slovenian brown bears (''Ursus arctos'')?|journal=Canadian Journal of Zoology|volume=81|issue=12|page=1996|doi=10.1139/z03-151|year=2003}}</ref> Locally heavy consumption of ants has been reported in [[North America]] as well, as in west-central [[Alberta]], 49% of scat contained ants.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Munro, R. H. M., Nielsen, S. E., Price, M. H., Stenhouse, G. B., & Boyce, M. S. |title=Seasonal and Diel Patterns of Grizzly Bear Diet and Activity in West-Central Alberta|journal=Journal of Mammalogy|volume=87|issue=6|page=1112|doi=10.1644/05-MAMM-A-410R3.1|year=2006}}</ref> This species mainly feed on ants with a passive response to the colony being dug out and low levels of formic acid, therefore [[carpenter ant]]s (''Camponotus'' ssp.), which are accessed through rotten logs rather than underground colonies, are preferred where available.<ref name= Swenson3/> Other important insect aggregations that brown bears feed heavily on in some regions include [[Coccinellidae|ladybirds]] and [[caddisfly]].<ref name= Ewer/> Brown bears living near coastal regions will regularly eat [[crab]]s and [[clam]]s. In Alaska's [[Katmai National Park and Preserve]], bears along the beaches of estuaries regularly dig through the sand for [[soft-shell clam]] (''Mya arenaria'') and [[Pacific razor clam]] (''Siliqua patula''), providing a more nutritious source of dietary energy in spring than plant life before fish become available there.<ref name="brown"/><ref>{{cite journal|author=Smith, T. S., & Partridge, S. T. |title=Dynamics of Intertidal Foraging by Coastal Brown Bears in Southwestern Alaska|journal=Journal of Wildlife Management|volume=68|issue=2|page=233|jstor=3803299|doi=10.2193/0022-541X(2004)068[0233:DOIFBC]2.0.CO;2|year=2004}}</ref> The zarigani (''[[Cambaroides japonicus]]''), a type of [[crayfish]], of [[Hokkaido]] is also an important, protein-rich dietary supplement for bears there.<ref name= Aoi/>

===Fish===
[[File:Alaskan Coastal Brown bear.....11.jpg|thumb|A freshly caught salmon is a very nutritious meal for an Alaska Peninsula brown bear.]]
By far the closest dietary relationship between brown bears and fish occurs between the salmon and trout of the genus ''[[Oncorhynchus]]'', particularly in coastal areas but also in some inland areas of [[North America]].<ref name="Hilderbrand"/> In the Kamchatka peninsula and several parts of coastal Alaska, including [[Kodiak Island]], brown bears feed largely on spawning [[salmon]], whose nutrition and abundance explain the enormous size of the bears in these areas.<ref name= Hilderbrand/><ref>{{cite journal|author=Mowat, G., & Heard, D. C. |title=Major components of grizzly bear diet across North America|journal=Canadian Journal of Zoology |volume=84|issue=3 |page=473 |doi=10.1139/z06-016|year=2006}}</ref> [[Sockeye salmon]] (''O. nerka'') and [[pink salmon]] (''O. gorbuscha'') are the two most commonly preyed upon, but many [[Coho salmon|coho]] (''O. kisutch''), [[Chinook salmon|Chinook]] (''O. tshawytscha''), [[Oncorhynchus masou|masu]] (''O. masou'') and [[chum salmon]] (''O. keta'') are also taken.<ref>Quinn, T. P. (2011). ''The behavior and ecology of Pacific salmon and trout''. UBC press.</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author=Ruggerone, G. T., Hanson, R., & Rogers, D. E. |title=Selective predation by brown bears (''Ursus arctos'') foraging on spawning sockeye salmon (''Oncorhynchus nerka'')|journal=Canadian Journal of Zoology |volume=78|issue=6 |page=974|doi=10.1139/z00-024|year=2000}}</ref><ref name= Helfield>{{cite journal|author=Helfield, J. M., & Naiman, R. J.|title=Keystone Interactions: Salmon and Bear in Riparian Forests of Alaska|journal=Ecosystems |volume=9|issue=2|page=167 |doi=10.1007/s10021-004-0063-5 |jstor=25470328|year=2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author=Dickerson, B. R., Quinn, T. P., & Willson, M. F.|title=Body size, arrival date, and reproductive success of pink salmon, ''Oncorhynchus gorbuscha''|journal=Ethology Ecology & Evolution |volume=14|page=29 |doi=10.1080/08927014.2002.9522759|year=2002}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author=Van Daele, M. B., Robbins, C. T., Semmens, B. X., Ward, E. J., Van Daele, L. J., & Leacock, W. B. |title=Salmon consumption by Kodiak brown bears (''Ursus arctos middendorffi'') with ecosystem management implications|journal=Canadian Journal of Zoology|volume=91|issue=3|page=164|doi=10.1139/cjz-2012-0221|year=2013}}</ref> Even in the coastal ranges of the Pacific, a diverse omnivorous diet is eaten, with the salmon spawning reliably providing food only in late summer and early fall. Exceptionally, salmon may come to inland rivers as early as June in the [[Katmai National Park and Preserve|Brooks River]] when other coastal Alaskan bears are in their dietary "lean period" and provide food for bears sooner than normal.<ref name= Kistchinski/> On Kodiak island, it appears the availability of alternative food sources is high, as berry crops are often profuse, marine organisms often wash up and ungulates both wild and domesticated are available.<ref name= Troyer/><ref>{{cite journal|author=Van Daele, L. J., Barnes Jr, V. G., & Belant, J. L. |title=Ecological flexibility of brown bears on Kodiak Island, Alaska|journal=Ursus|volume=23|page=21|doi=10.2192/URSUS-D-10-00022.1|jstor=41818968|year=2012}}</ref> The fishing techniques of bears are well-documented. They often congregate around falls when the salmon are forced to breach the water, at which point the bears will try to catch the fish in mid-air (often with their mouths). They will also wade into shallow waters, hoping to pin a slippery salmon with their claws.<ref name= Hilderbrand/><ref>{{cite journal |url=https://www.nps.gov/glba/learn/nature/upload/Consumption%20choice%20by%20bears.pdf|author=Gende, S. M., Quinn, T. P., & Willson, M. F. |title=Consumption choice by bears feeding on salmon |journal=Oecologia |volume=127 |issue=3 |pages=372–382 |doi=10.1007/s004420000590|pmid=28547108 |year=2001 |bibcode=2001Oecol.127..372G }}</ref> While they may eat almost all the parts of the fish, bears at the peak of spawning, when there is usually a glut of fish to feed on, may eat only the most nutritious parts of the salmon (including the eggs and head) and then indifferently leave the rest of the carcass to scavengers, which can include [[red fox]]es (''Vulpes vulpes''), [[bald eagle]]s (''Haliaeetus leucocephalus''), [[common raven]]s (''Corvus corax'') and [[gull]]s.<ref name= Helfield/> Despite their normally solitary habits, brown bears will gather rather closely in numbers at good spawning sites. The largest and most powerful males claim the most fruitful fishing spots and bears (especially males) will sometimes fight over the rights to a prime fishing spot.<ref name="brown"/><ref>{{cite journal|author=Stonorov, D., & Stokes, A. W. |year=1972|title=Social behavior of the Alaska brown bear|journal= Bears: Their Biology and Management|pages= 232–242}}</ref> Despite their aggressive defensive abilities, female brown bears usually select sub-optimal fishing spots to avoid male bears that could potentially threaten their cubs.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Ben-David, M., Titus, K., & Beier, L. R. |title=Consumption of salmon by Alaskan brown bears: A trade-off between nutritional requirements and the risk of infanticide? |journal=Oecologia |volume=138|issue=3|pages=465–74 |pmid=14673639 |year=2004|doi=10.1007/s00442-003-1442-x|bibcode=2004Oecol.138..465B}}</ref>

One other key relationship occurs between brown bears and ''Oncorhynchus'' species occurs with the grizzly bear and the [[cutthroat trout]] (''O. clarki'') in the [[Rocky Mountains|Rockies]] such as around [[Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem|Yellowstone]]. Here this species was consumed in considerable numbers although, like the whitebark pine nut, this food source has declined due to invasive species introduced by man, i.e. invasive trout which are outcompeting cutthroat trout.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Mattson, D. J., & Reinhart, D. P. |title=Influences of cutthroat trout (''Oncorhynchus clarki'') on behaviour and reproduction of Yellowstone grizzly bears (''Ursus arctos''), 1975–1989|journal=Canadian Journal of Zoology|volume=73|issue=11|page=2072|doi=10.1139/z95-244|year=1995}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author=Reinhart, D. P., & Mattson, D. J. |year=1990|title=Bear use of cutthroat trout spawning streams in Yellowstone National Park|journal=Bears: Their Biology and Management|pages= 343–350|url=http://www.bearbiology.com/fileadmin/tpl/Downloads/URSUS/Vol_8/Reinhart_Mattson_8.pdf|jstor= 3872938|volume=8}}</ref><ref>Koel, T. M., Bigelow, P. E., Doepke, P. D., Ertel, B. D., & Mahony, D. L. (2005). ''Nonnative lake trout result in Yellowstone cutthroat trout decline and impacts to bears and anglers''. Fisheries, 30(11), 10–19.</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author=Ruzycki, J. R., Beauchamp, D. A., & Yule, D. L. |title=Effects of Introduced Lake Trout on Native Cutthroat Trout in Yellowstone Lake|journal=Ecological Applications|volume=13|pages=23–37|doi=10.1890/1051-0761(2003)013[0023:EOILTO]2.0.CO;2|jstor=3099948|year=2003}}</ref> The now extinct [[California grizzly bear]] was also a fairly specialized ''Onocorhynchus'' predator in California's mountain streams and rivers, principally of [[rainbow trout]] (''O. mykiss'').<ref name=Storer1955/> Outside of Pacific-based salmonids, predatory relationships between brown bears and fish are uncommon. Predation on [[broad whitefish]] (''Coregonus nasus'') and [[longnose sucker]]s (''Catostomus catostomus'') has been reported in sub-Arctic Canada and [[northern pike]] (''Esox lucius'') and [[Grayling (species)|grayling]] (''Thymallus thymallus'') in Siberia, plus other older records of brown bears hunting miscellaneous freshwater fish in Eurasia.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Barker, O. E., & Derocher, A. E. |title=Brown bear (''Ursus arctos'') predation of broad whitefish (''Coregonus nasus'') in the Mackenzie Delta region, Northwest Territories|journal=ARCTIC|volume=62|issue=3|jstor=40513309|doi=10.14430/arctic151|year=2009}}</ref><ref name= Gau>{{cite journal|author1=Gau, R. J. |author2=Case, R. |author3=Penner, D. F. |author4= McLoughlin, P. D. |year=2002|title=Feeding patterns of barren-ground grizzly bears in the central Canadian Arctic|jstor=40512491|journal= Arctic|pages= 339–344|url=http://pubs.aina.ucalgary.ca/arctic/arctic55-4-339.pdf|volume=55|issue=4 |doi=10.14430/arctic717}}</ref>

===Mammals===
Beyond the regular predation of salmon, most brown bears are not particularly active predators.<ref name="brown"/> Nonetheless, brown bears are capable of obtaining practically all forms of the mammals that they encounter: from mouse-like rodents to those as fearsome as a [[tiger]] or as large as a [[bison]].<ref name=role>{{cite book|publisher=International Conference in Dnepropetrovsk |title=Роль Бурого Медведя в Экосистемах Дальнего Востока России |trans-title=Role of the Brown Bear in the Ecosystem of Far East Russia |language=Russian |url=http://www.wcsrussia.org/DesktopModules/Bring2mind/DMX/Download.aspx?EntryId=3343&PortalId=32&DownloadMethod=attachment|author=Seryodkin, I.V.|pages=502–503|year=2007}}</ref><ref name= Wyman>{{cite journal|author=Wyman, T. |year=2002|title=Grizzly bear predation on a bull bison in Yellowstone National Park|journal= Ursus|volume=13|pages= 375–377|url=http://www.bearbiology.com/fileadmin/tpl/Downloads/URSUS/Vol_13/Wyman_13.pdf}}</ref> Over 100 species of mammal have been recorded either in the scats of brown bears or have been observed as being killed or consumed by the species, although much of this consumption probably represents merely scavenging on carrion.<ref name= Smith/><ref name= Forsyth>Forsyth, A. (1999). ''Mammals of North America: temperate and arctic regions''. Firefly Books.</ref>

[[File:A PARKA SQUIRREL BURROWS NEAR THE WEST BANK OF THE SAGAVANIRKTOK RIVER. THE GROUND HAS BEEN PAWED UP BY A BARREN... - NARA - 550465.jpg|thumb|An [[Arctic ground squirrel]] burrow that has been excavated by a hunting barren-ground grizzly bear]]
A perhaps surprisingly high balance of mammalian foods consists of [[rodent]]s or similar smallish [[mammal]]s, as about half of the species consumed by brown bears weigh less than {{convert|10|kg|lb|abbr=on}} on average. These may include [[hare]]s (''Lepus'' ssp.), [[pika]]s (''Ochotona'' ssp.) [[marmot]]s (''Marmota'' ssp.), [[ground squirrel]]s, [[chipmunk]]s, [[Mouse|mice]], [[rat]]s, [[lemming]]s and [[vole]]s. Due to their propensity for digging, brown bears are able to smell out active subterranean burrows of these small mammals and either wait quietly or furiously dig away until the animals are either displaced and lunged at or are cornered in their burrows.<ref name= Smith/><ref name="brown"/><ref name= Gau/> Not only do they consume the small mammals, but they also feed on their caches, as has been recorded in grizzly bears attacking [[vole]]s and [[northern pocket gopher]]s (''Thomomys talpoides'').<ref>{{cite journal|author=Mattson, D. J. |year=2004|title=Consumption of voles and vole food caches by Yellowstone grizzly bears: exploratory analyses|jstor=3872975|journal= Ursus|volume=15|issue=2|pages=218–226|doi=10.2192/1537-6176(2004)015<0218:COVAVF>2.0.CO;2}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author=Mattson, D. J.|title=Exploitation of Pocket Gophers and Their Food Caches by Grizzly Bears|journal=Journal of Mammalogy|volume=85|issue=4|page=731|doi=10.1644/BJK-125|year=2004}}</ref> In some areas, caches may be the primary target when bears dig at these animal's burrows, as may be the case with [[Siberian chipmunk]]s (''Eutamias sibiricus''), whose hoards can contain up to {{convert|20|kg|lb|abbr=on}} of food, with the chipmunks themselves only being caught occasionally.<ref name= Seryodkin/> With particular regularity, tundra-dwelling grizzlies will wait at burrows of [[Arctic ground squirrel]]s (''Spermophilus parryii'') hoping to pick off a few of the {{convert|1|kg|lb|abbr=on}} rodents. Ground squirrel hunting is most successful in September and October, when early snow may impede the rodents' rocky escape routes. In [[Denali National Park]], Arctic ground squirrels represent about 8% of the year-round diet of grizzly bears and are the most consistent source of animal protein for grizzlies there.<ref name= Pearson/><ref name= Murie/><ref name="Brown">{{cite web|url=http://www.weaselwords.com/page/ferret_art036.php|title=Inherited behavior traits of the domesticated ferret|last=Brown|first=Susan, A|publisher=weaselwords.com}}</ref> An even more important dietary relationship with a small mammal occurs in the [[Tibetan blue bear]], which is apparently the most completely carnivorous brown bear type, foraging most regularly for [[plateau pika]]s (''Ochotona curzoniae''), a species about one-sixth the weight of an Arctic ground squirrel.<ref name= Aichun>{{cite journal|author=Aichun, X., Zhigang, J., Chunwang, L., Jixun, G., Guosheng, W., & Ping, C. |title=Summer food habits of brown bears in Kekexili Nature Reserve, Qinghai-Tibetan plateau, China|journal=Ursus|volume=17|issue=2|pages=132–137|jstor=3873090|doi=10.2192/1537-6176(2006)17[132:SFHOBB]2.0.CO;2|year=2006}}</ref> As many as 25 pikas have been found in a single bear's stomach and in [[Changtang]], 60% of the diet consisted of pikas.<ref>Chapman, J. A., & Flux, J. E. (1990). [https://portals.iucn.org/library/node/6047 ''Rabbits, hares and pikas: status survey and conservation action plan'']. IUCN.</ref> Where plateau pikas are absent, as in the [[Upper Mustang|Mustang region]] of [[Nepal]], [[Himalayan marmot]]s (''Marmota himalayana'') become the dietary staple of the bear, occurring in about half of nearly a thousand scats.<ref name= Aryal/> Large rodents such as [[beaver]]s (''Castor'' spp.) and [[North American porcupine]]s (''Erethizon dorsatum'') are rare prey items, mostly due to differing habitat preferences, as well as the obvious defenses of the latter.<ref name= Murie/><ref name= Edwards>Edwards, M. (2005). [http://www.enr.gov.nt.ca/sites/default/files/delta_grizzly_project_2004_annual_report.pdf ''Ecology of Grizzly Bears (''Ursus arctos'') in the Mackenzie Delta oil and gas development area'']. University of Alberta, Department of Biological Sciences.</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author=Rosell, F., Bozser, O., Collen, P., & Parker, H. |title=Ecological impact of beavers ''Castor fiber'' and ''Castor canadensis'' and their ability to modify ecosystems|journal=Mammal Review|volume=35|issue=3–4|pages=248–276|doi=10.1111/j.1365-2907.2005.00067.x|year=2005|hdl=11250/2438080}}</ref> Up to five species of [[cetacean]] have been recorded as a food source in the coastal regions of [[Alaska]], the [[Central Arctic]] and (formerly) [[California]] when beached.<ref name= Edwards/><ref>{{cite journal|author=Lewis, T. M., & Lafferty, D. J. |title=Brown bears and wolves scavenge humpback whale carcass in Alaska|journal=Ursus|volume=25|page=8|doi=10.2192/URSUS-D-14-00004.1|year=2014}}</ref>

In most of their range, brown bears regularly feed on [[ungulate]]s. In many cases, this important food source is obtained as carrion. Carrion is mostly eaten in spring, when winter snow and ice conditions (including snow-slides) and starvation claim many ungulate lives. As carcasses are often solidly frozen when encountered, brown bears may sit on them to thaw them sufficiently for consumption. While perhaps a majority of bears of the species will charge at ungulates at some point in their lives, many predation attempts start with the bear clumsily and half-heartedly pursuing the prey, and end with the prey escaping alive.<ref name="brown"/> On the other hand, some brown bears are quite self-assured predators who habitually pursue and catch large prey items, mainly ungulates. Such bears are usually taught how to hunt by their mothers from an early age.<ref name="brown"/> They are the most regular predator of ungulates among extant bear species.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Oldfield, C. C., McHenry, C. R., Clausen, P. D., Chamoli, U., Parr, W. C. H., Stynder, D. D., & Wroe, S. |title=Finite element analysis of ursid cranial mechanics and the prediction of feeding behaviour in the extinct giant ''Agriotherium africanum'' |journal=Journal of Zoology|volume=286|issue=2|page=171|doi=10.1111/j.1469-7998.2011.00862.x|year=2012}}</ref> The extent of hunting behavior differs by region. For example, in [[Slovenia]], ungulate meat was four times more likely to be obtained as carrion than through hunting, while on the contrary in east-central [[Alaska]], live hunting of ungulates was four times more likely than scavenging of carrion.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Sidorovich, V. E. |year=2006|title=Ecological studies on brown bear (''Ursus arctos'') in Belarus: distribution, population trends and dietary structure|journal=Acta Zoologica Lituanica|volume=16|issue=3|page=185|doi=10.1080/13921657.2006.10512729}}</ref><ref name= Boertje>{{cite journal|author=Boertje, R. D., Gasaway, W. C., Grangaard, D. V., & Kelleyhouse, D. G.|title=Predation on moose and caribou by radio-collared grizzly bears in east central Alaska|journal=Canadian Journal of Zoology |volume=66|issue=11 |page=2492 |doi=10.1139/z88-369|year=1988}}</ref> The extent of carnivory in brown bears has been proven to increase at northern latitudes.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Vulla, E., Hobson, K. A., Korsten, M., Leht, M., Martin, A. J., Lind, A., Mannil, P., Valdmann, H. & Saarma, U. |title=Carnivory is Positively Correlated with Latitude among Omnivorous Mammals: Evidence from Brown Bears, Badgers and Pine Martens |journal=Annales Zoologici Fennici|volume=46|issue=6|page=395|doi=10.5735/086.046.0601|year=2009}}</ref> When brown bears attack these large animals, they usually target young or infirm ones, as they are easier to catch. Successful hunts usually occur after a short rush and ambush but they may chase down prey in the open and will try to separate mother and young. Prey is usually killed when the bear grabs the rib cage over the back and delivers a bite to the back of the head, neck, face or nose.<ref>{{cite web|author=Mattson, David|publisher=Southwest Biological Science Center|title=Foraging Behavior of North American Bears |url=http://sbsc.wr.usgs.gov/cprs/research/projects/grizzly/pdf/FORAGINGBEHAVIOROFNORTHAMERICANBEARS.pdf|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070711074612/http://sbsc.wr.usgs.gov/cprs/research/projects/grizzly/pdf/FORAGINGBEHAVIOROFNORTHAMERICANBEARS.pdf|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2007-07-11}}</ref> The bear may also pin its prey (usually young) to the ground and then immediately tear and eat it alive.<ref>{{cite journal | last1=French |first1= S. P. |last2= French |first2=M. G. |title=Predatory behavior of grizzly bears feeding on elk calves in Yellowstone National Park, 1986–1988 |year= 1990 |journal=International Conf. Bear Res. And Manage | volume= 8|pages= 335–341|url=http://www.bearbiology.com/fileadmin/tpl/Downloads/URSUS/Vol_8/French_French_8.pdf | format = PDF | doi=10.2307/3872937|jstor= 3872937}}</ref> Despite being characterized as unskilled predators with minimally-refined hunting skills, most individual bears who are routine ungulate predators have shown the ability to vary their hunting strategy and have hunting success rates comparable to other large, solitary carnivorans.<ref>{{cite journal|author1=Frackowiak, W. |author2=Gula, R. |year=1997|title=Diet and food habits of the brown bear (''Ursus arctos'' L.) in Polish eastern Carpathians|journal= Journal Wildlife Research|volume= 2|issue=2|pages=154–160|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/271829248}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author=Gunther, K. A., & Renkin, R. A. |title=Grizzly Bear Predation on Elk Calves and Other Fauna of Yellowstone National Park|journal=Bears: Their Biology and Management|volume=8|page=329|doi=10.2307/3872936|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/236611922|jstor=3872936|year=1990}}</ref> Brown bears will on occasion bite or swipe at some prey in order to stun it enough to knock it over for consumption.<ref name= Macdonald/> To pick out young or infirm individuals, bears will charge at herds so the slower-moving and more vulnerable individuals will be made apparent. Brown bears may also ambush young animals by finding them via scent.<ref name= Smith/> Despite being characterized as a danger primarily to young, spring neonatal ungulates in the first couple of days of life, when they have undeveloped legs and cannot run at full speed, young ungulates may be pursued well into summer or fall after they have developed running abilities.<ref name= Zager>{{cite journal|author=Zager, P., & Beecham, J. |title=The role of American black bears and brown bears as predators on ungulates in North America |journal=Ursus |volume=17 |issue=2|pages=95–108|jstor=3873087 |doi=10.2192/1537-6176(2006)17[95:TROABB]2.0.CO;2|year=2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author=Barber, S. M., Mech, L. D., & White, P. J. |year=2005|title=Bears remain top summer predators|journal=Yellowstone Science |volume=13|issue=3 |pages=37–44 |url=http://www.mednscience.org/files/pdf/ys1-barber.pdf}}</ref> Most attacks on adult ungulates occur when the prey has some variety of physical disadvantage. When emerging from hibernation, brown bears, whose broad paws allow them to walk over most ice and snow, may pursue large prey such as moose, whose hooves cannot support them on encrusted snow.<ref name= Macdonald/> Similarly, predatory attacks on large prey sometimes occur at riverbeds, when it is more difficult for the prey specimen to run away due to muddy or slippery soil.<ref name= Smith/> On rare occasions, most importantly when confronting unusually large, fully-grown and dangerous prey, bears kill them by hitting with their powerful forearms, which can break the necks and backs of large creatures such as adult moose and adult bison.<ref name="brown"/><ref>{{cite journal|author=Elgmork, K. |year=1978|title=Striking blows by the brown bear |journal=Fauna|volume= 31|issue=3|pages=157–164}}</ref>

[[File:Grizzly bear on bison carcass (8703043728).jpg|thumb|left|A grizzly bear feasts on a bison carcass in Yellowstone.]]
The leading ungulate prey for brown bears is normally deer. Up to a dozen species have been eaten by brown bears but the main prey species are the larger species they encounter: [[elk]] (''Cervus canadensis''), [[moose]] (''Alces alces'') and [[Caribou (North America)|caribou]] (''Rangifer tarandus''). Larger deer are preferred because they tend to be less agile and swift than small or medium-sized deer (although a caribou can handily outpace a grizzly bear in the open), they are found in large quantities in several areas inhabited by brown bears and provide a larger meal per carcass.<ref name= Smith/><ref name= Boertje/> Moose may be preferred where found in large numbers because of their solitary habits and tendency to dwell in wooded areas, both of which makes them easier to ambush.<ref name= Mattson>{{cite journal|author=Mattson, D. J., Blanchard, B. M., & Knight, R. R. |title=Food habits of Yellowstone grizzly bears, 1977–1987|journal=Canadian Journal of Zoology|volume=69|issue=6|page=1619|doi=10.1139/z91-226|url=https://fresc.usgs.gov/products/papers/106_Mattson.pdf|year=1991}}</ref> Despite its diminished reputation as a predator, the brown bear is the most dangerous solitary predator of moose, with only packs of wolves a more regular predator; even [[Siberian tiger]]s take other prey, primarily ([[elk]] and [[Wild boar|boar]]), in areas where they co-exist with the giant deer.<ref name= Mattson/><ref name= Persson>{{cite journal | last1 = Persson | first1 = I. L. | last2 = Wikan | first2 = S. | last3 = Swenson | first3 = J. E. | last4 = Mysterud | first4 = I. | year = 2001 | title = The diet of the brown bear Ursus arctos in the Pasvik Valley, northeastern Norway | journal = Wildlife Biology | volume = 7 | issue = 1| pages = 27–37 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title=Food habits of Amur tigers in the Sikhote-Alin Zapovednik and the Russian Far East, and implications for conservation |url=http://www.panthera.org/sites/default/files/Miquelle_Quigley_1996_Food_habits_of_Amur_tigers.pdf |author=Miquelle, Dale G. |journal=Journal of Wildlife Research |year=1996 |volume=1 |issue=2 |page=138 |display-authors=etal |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121101192450/http://www.panthera.org/sites/default/files/Miquelle_Quigley_1996_Food_habits_of_Amur_tigers.pdf |archivedate=1 November 2012 |df=dmy }}</ref> Brown bears normally avoid the potential risks of hunting large deer, which can potentially fight back but usually escape bears by running, by picking out young calves or sickly adults from deer herds.<ref name= Smith/><ref>{{cite journal|author=Mattson, D. J. |title=Use of ungulates by Yellowstone grizzly bears ''Ursus arctos''|journal=Biological Conservation|volume=81|page=161|doi=10.1016/S0006-3207(96)00142-5|year=1997}}</ref> In northeastern [[Norway]], it was found that moose were the most important single food item (present in up to 45% of scats and locally comprising more than 70% of the bear's dietary energy) for local brown bears and several local bears appear to be specialized moose hunters, most often picking off sickly yearling moose and pregnant but healthy cows.<ref name= Persson/> In [[Yellowstone National Park]], grizzly bears who derived much of their food energy from ungulates were studied, and 30% of the ungulates consumed were through predation, the remaining amount from scavenging of carcasses. Elk, bison and moose (the three largest native ungulates in the region) each constituted nearly a quarter of the overall ungulate diet. 13% of the total of ungulates actively hunted and killed per that study in Yellowstone were elk calves, while 8% of the actively and successfully hunted prey there were adult cow elk.<ref>{{cite journal | last1 = Mattson | first1 = D. J. | year = 1997 | title = Use of ungulates by Yellowstone grizzly bears Ursus arctos | journal = Biological Conservation | volume = 81 | issue = 1| pages = 161–177 | doi=10.1016/s0006-3207(96)00142-5}}</ref> Despite their lack of preference for smaller deer, other species including [[red deer]] (''Cervus elaphus''), [[sika deer]] (''Cervus nippon'' ), [[axis deer]] (''Axis axis''), [[roe deer|European roe deer]] (''Capreolus capreolus''), [[Siberian roe deer]] (''Capreolus pygargus''), [[fallow deer]] (''Dama dama''), [[mule deer]] (''Odocoileus hemionus'') and [[white-tailed deer]] (''Odocoileus virginianus'') have turned up in their diet.<ref name= Smith/><ref name= Naves/><ref name= Zager/><ref>{{cite journal|author=Ballard, W. B., Lutz, D., Keegan, T. W., Carpenter, L. H., & deVos Jr, J. C. |year=2001|title=Deer-predator relationships: a review of recent North American studies with emphasis on mule and black-tailed deer|journal=Wildlife Society Bulletin|pages= 99–115|jstor=3783986|volume=29|issue=1|url=https://nrm.dfg.ca.gov/FileHandler.ashx?DocumentID=51048}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author=Zidon, R., Saltz, D., Shore, L. S., and Motro, U. |title=Behavioral changes, stress, and survival following reintroduction of Persian fallow deer from two breeding facilities|journal=Conservation Biology|volume=23|issue=4|pages=1026–35|pmid=19210305|year=2009|doi=10.1111/j.1523-1739.2008.01163.x}}</ref>

As many as 20 species of [[bovid]]s are also potential prey, including various [[ovis|sheep]], [[capra (genus)|goat]]s, [[antelope]], [[bison]] (''Bison'' ssp.) and [[muskoxen]] (''Ovibos moschatus''). Bovids are mostly taken in random encounters when bears come across a vulnerable, usually young or sickly individual, as smaller species are extremely agile (and often live in rocky environments) and larger varieties are potentially dangerous, especially if aware of the bear's presence.<ref name= Murie/><ref>{{cite journal|author=Fico, R., Locati, M., & Lovari, S. |year=1984|title=A case of brown bear predation on ''Abruzzo chamois''|journal= Säugetierkdl Mitt|volume= 31|pages= 185–187}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author=Xu, A. C., Jiang, Z. G., Li, C. W., & Cai, P. |year=2010|title=Food habits and hunting patterns of Tibetan brown bear during warm seasons in Kekexili region on Qinghai-Tibetan Plateau|journal=Dong Wu Xue Yan Jiu= Zoological Research|volume=31|issue=6|pages=670–674}}</ref> In some parts of [[eastern Europe]] and [[Russia]], [[wild boar]] (''Sus scrofa'') may be taken in surprisingly large quantities considering the mostly herbivorous reputation of bears in these regions. One study from the [[Amur Oblast|Amur territory]] of [[Russia]] found that brown bears were actually more prolific killers of wild boars than both tigers and gray wolves, but these results are probably biased due to the scarcity of tigers in the region because of overhunting of the big cat.<ref name= Smith/><ref>{{cite journal|author=Slobodyan, A. A. |year=1976|title=The European brown bear in the Carpathians|journal=Bears: Their Biology and Management|pages= 313–319}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author=Rakov, N. V. |year=1970|title=Causes of mortality of the wild boar and its interrelation with predators in the Amur territory|journal=Zoologicheskii Zhurnal|volume= 49|pages=1220–1228}}</ref> In rare cases, brown bears are capable of killing bulls of the largest ungulates in regions they inhabit, reportedly including [[moose]], [[muskox]], [[wild yak]] (''Bos grunniens'') and both [[American bison|American]] and [[European bison]] (''Bison bison'' & ''bonasus''). Remarkably, such attacks are sometimes carried out by bears that were not particularly large, including interior sow grizzlies or small-bodied bears from the [[Central Arctic]], and some exceptional ungulates taken may be up to two to three times the weight of the attacking bear.<ref name= Aryal/><ref name= Wyman/><ref name= Boertje/><ref>{{cite journal|author=Leslie, D. M., & Schaller, G. B. |doi=10.1644/836.1 |year=2009|title=''Bos grunniens'' and ''Bos mutus'' (Artiodactyla: Bovidae|journal=Mammalian Species |volume= 836|pages= 1–17|url=http://www.mammalogy.org/uploads/Leslie%20and%20Schaller%202009.pdf}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author=Reynolds, P. E., Reynolds, H. V., & Shideler, R. T. |journal=Ursus |volume=13|pages=79–84 |year=2002|url=https://www.adfg.alaska.gov/static/home/library/pdfs/wildlife/propubs/reynolds.pdf|title=Predation and multiple kills of muskoxen by grizzly bears}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author=Gunn, A., & Miller, F. L. |year=1982|title=Muskox bull killed by a barren-ground grizzly bear, Thelon Game Sanctuary, NWT|journal=Arctic|volume= 35|issue=4|pages= 545–546|url=http://pubs.aina.ucalgary.ca/arctic/Arctic35-4-545.pdf|doi=10.14430/arctic2364}}</ref><ref name= Persson2>Persson, I. L. (1998). ''Brown bear Ursus arctos predation upon adult moose Alces alces in Scandinavia: a study at two levels of scale''. Cand. scient. thesis.</ref><ref name= Okarma>{{cite journal|author=Okarma, H., Jędrzejewska, B., Jędrzejewski, W., Krasiński, Z. A., & Miłkowski, L. |year=1995|title=The roles of predation, snow cover, acorn crop, and man-related factors on ungulate mortality in Białowieża Primeval Forest, Poland|journal=Acta Theriologica|volume= 40|issue=2|pages=197–217|url=http://rcin.org.pl/Content/12344/BI002_2613_Cz-40-2_Acta-T40-nr17-197-217_o.pdf|doi=10.4098/at.arch.95-20}}</ref> However, most of the bears who took adult moose in east-central [[Alaska]] and [[Scandinavia]] were large, mature males.<ref name= Boertje/><ref name= Persson2/><ref>{{cite journal|author=Dahle, B., Wallin, K., Cederlund, G., Persson, I. L., Selvaag, L. S., & Swenson, J. ===Other vertebrates===
This species may eat [[bird]]s and their [[Egg (biology)|egg]]s, including almost entirely ground- or rock-nesting species. Although not typically able to capture a healthy grown bird, eggs, nestlings and fledglings of large bird species can be very attractive to brown bears.<ref name="brown"/> Species attacked have ranged can be any size available from [[Aleutian tern]]s (''Onychoprion aleuticus'') to [[Trumpeter swan|trumpeter]] and [[whooper swan]]s (''Cygnus buccinator'' & ''cygnus'').<ref>{{cite book|author=Buckley, F. G., & Buckley, P. A. |year=1980|chapter=Do Aleutian Terns Exhibit Extraordinary Anti-Predator Adaptations?|jstor=4626703|title= Proceedings of the Colonial Waterbird Group |volume=3|pages=99–107|publisher=Waterbird Society}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author=Henson, P., & Grant, T.
